title-group.article-title: Combined Aldosterone and Cortisol Secretion by Adrenal Incidentaloma

author-notes.corresp: Valentina Vicennati, Division of Endocrinology, Department of Clinical Medicine, S. Orsola-Malpighi Hospital, University Alma Mater Studiorum, Via Massarenti 9, 40138 Bologna, Italy Email: vicennati@aosp.bo.it

abstract.p: A 70-year-old woman was referred to the authors’ unit following hospitalization for cardiac failure, high urinary free cortisol concentrations and severe hypokaliemia. A computed tomography scan of the abdomen showed an adrenal adenoma. The 24-hour urinary free cortisol values were high and plasma cortisol levels failed to suppress following 1 mg dexamethasone test. Aldosterone to plasma renin activity ratio was also pathologic, confirmed by saline load. She showed no symptoms of glucocorticoid excess. She was diagnosed with combined primary hyperaldosteronism and Cushing’s syndrome. Cases of adrenal incidentalomas co-secreting cortisol and aldosterone are rare; they should be addressed in patients undergoing adrenal surgery for Conn’s syndrome to avoid adrenal insufficiency after removal of the tumor.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Among forms of endocrine hypertension, the most frequent are an excess of glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and catecholamines.1 The simultaneous production by adrenal adenomas of both cortisol and aldosterone is wrongly thought to be rare.2-4 From the histological point of view, it is not easy to discriminate these mixed forms. We report a case of a woman with simultaneous hyperaldosteronism and Cushing’s syndrome caused by adrenal adenoma. She underwent surgery, and glucocorticoid replacement was unnecessary.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: A 70-year-old woman was hospitalized for cardiac failure and severe hypokaliemia. She had a history of obesity associated with metabolic syndrome (dyslipidemia, hypertension, type 2 diabetes). Two years earlier, she underwent a computed tomography scan for abdominal pain, and an adrenal tumor was incidentally found (maximum diameter of 15 mm), radiologically consistent with adenoma. During hospitalization, high urinary free cortisol (UFC) levels were found. A computed tomography scan of the abdomen was thus performed, showing an enlargement of the left adrenal mass (from 15 to 29 mm; Figure 1, upper panel).

caption.p: Computed tomography scan of adrenal tumor (upper panel) and 131I-6-β-iodomethyl-norcholesterol (lower panel) scintigraphy

Abdominal computed tomography showed a round, well-defined mass of 24.5 × 29 mm diameter in the left adrenal gland. 131I-6-β-iodomethyl-norcholesterol scan showed the increased uptake at left adrenal level, without inhibition of the controlateral adrenal gland.

sec.p: Following discharge from hospital, the patient was admitted to our unit for functional evaluation of the adrenal tumor that was never evaluated before.

Her medications included aspirin (100 mg/d), candesartan and hydrochlorothiazide (16 mg + 12.5 mg/d, respectively), amlodipine (5 mg/d), atenolol (100 mg/d), doxazosin (4 mg/d), atorvastatin (10 mg/d), gliquidone (15 mg/d), lansoprazole (30 mg/d), and potassium supplementation (48 mEq/d). On admission, her body weight was 84 kg, body mass index 33.6 kg/m2, waist circumference 103 cm, hip circumference 109 cm (waist-to-hip ratio = 0.94); she had bilateral malleolar edema. Arterial blood pressure was 150/80 mm Hg, sinusal rhythm (76 beats/min). There were no buffalo humps and no rubra striae.
Functional evaluation of adrenal activity was performed without any pharmacological interference, in accordance with the cardiologist. Potassium supplementation was continued.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Biochemical parameters were normal. Lipid profile was normal, except high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels (44 mg/dL). Catecholamines and their urinary metabolites were normal. Fasting basal cortisol levels were repeatedly high as well as UFC/24 hours, and cortisol suppression after 1 mg dexamethasone (11:00 pm) was partial (Table 1); the aldosterone to plasma renin activity ratio (ARR), following 2 hours orthostatism, was abnormally high (Table 1). The saline infusion test also resulted in a partial suppression of aldosterone levels (from 295 to 95 pg/mL; Table 1).

caption.p: Hormonal and Electrolyte Assessment Before and After Surgical Removal of the Adenoma

fn.p: Abbreviations: ACTH, adrenocorticotropic hormone; UFC, urinary free cortisol; DHEA, dehydroepiandrosterone; 17-OHP, 17-hydroxyprogesterone; ARR, aldosterone to plasma renin activity ratio.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Under oral replacement 48 mEq/d and following 4 weeks of no pharmacological interference.

fn.label: b
fn.p: To convert to nmol/L, divide by 10 and multiply by 27.59.

sec.p: A 131I-6-β-iodomethyl-norcholesterol scan was performed, showing an increased uptake at left adrenal level, without functional inhibition of the controlateral adrenal gland (Figure 1). The patient underwent laparoscopic surgery. During surgery, an adrenal adenoma of 2 cm was removed. The cut surface of the tumor was yellow, which is typical of aldosterone-secreting adenomas.

Histologically, a cortical neoplasm with spironolactone bodies was found (Figure 2). According to the Weiss score system, the following findings were noted: low nuclear grade with focal high nuclear grade areas, mitotic rate of 4 per 50 high-power field, no atypical mitotic figures, eosinophilic tumor cell cytoplasm in more than 75% of all tumor cells, diffuse architecture, no necrosis, no venous or sinusoidal invasion, and no capsular invasion (Figure 2). A final Weiss score less than 3 and the small dimension indicated a benign neoplasm.

caption.p: Cortical neoplasm showing sipronolactone bodies (upper panel, arrows) and the unbroken capsula of the tumor (hematoxylin–eosin; lower panel)

sec.p: Glucocorticoid replacement therapy was required immediately after surgery and then gradually stopped. The right adrenal gland was functioning normally. Potassium supplementation was gradually stopped and normokaliemia was present at the next controls (Table 1).

Four months after the surgical procedure, a 1 mg dexamethasone suppression test was repeated; cortisol values were normal, and the AAR was normalized, as well as aldosterone values following saline load test (Table 1). Arterial blood pressure was better controlled by antihypertensive therapy, which was markedly reduced, as follows: atenolol (50 mg/d), candesartan and hydrochlorothiazide (16 mg + 12.5 mg/d, respectively).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Diagnosis of Cushing’s syndrome, as well as of primary hyperaldosteronism, associated with adrenal adenoma is not always easy to perform, especially when it is not associated with strong clinical evidence. Moreover, by performing a PubMed research through MEDLINE starting from 1970 up to 2011, we found 37 reports of well-described co-secretion of both cortisol and aldosterone from adrenal tumors.2-12

In the case presented here, a possible confounding element was the presence of obesity, which could justify both type 2 diabetes and uncontrolled hypertension. The diagnosis was made because of the presence of an adrenal incidentaloma.

Späth et al13 published data from 8 patients followed in the past 10 years, with co-secretion of both cortisol and aldosterone by a unilateral adrenal tumor or adrenal hyperplasia. Tests used to screen aldosterone secretion are quite similar to the investigations used in our case. On the contrary, cortisol secretion by adrenal was differently assessed (ie, no dexamethasone suppression test, but only stimulatory tests). For this reason, even though we do not agree with the methods applied in this article, we agree with the authors on the general concept that patients with adrenal tumors must be screened for excess of different hormonal secretions.13
It is still a matter of debate why adrenal adenomas are able to co-secrete 2 different hormones, coming from different secretory pathways.

The adrenal cortex is divided into 3 functionally distinct zones, able to synthesize different hormones depending on the specific enzymatic pathways.14 To date, the reason why adrenal adenomas can express multiple different enzymatic pathways is still unknown.15,16 Studies performed in fetal primates have shown that each adrenal zone may acquire the capacity to synthesize specific hormones during gestational age.14 Whether this may also occur in humans is unknown.

Aldosterone-secreting adenomas have a typical golden yellow cut surface,17 even though from the histological point of view, it is very difficult to distinguish aldosterone- from cortisol-secreting forms. The formation of spironolactone (S) bodies is induced by S through direct and indirect effects of S on the zona glomerulosa (zG).18 The indirect effects are thought to be mediated through stimulation of zG cells by a reactivated deficiency because of sodium diuresis after the administration of S. The direct effects of S have been hypothesized as being based on the turnover of endoplasmic reticulum of zG cells.18 S bodies were found in the adrenal cortices of patients affected by Conn’s syndrome or treated with S.19 Interestingly, in this case, the cytoplasm of the tumor cells contained structures resembling spironolactone bodies, but the patient had never had treatment with S. To our knowledge, this is the first case described in the literature, and the pathophysiological mechanism is unknown.
Other techniques, such as immunohistochemical analyses, can be used to identify aldosterone-producing adenomas,3 even though there is no general agreement about the sensitivity of these antibodies.

Our case report emphasizes the need to preoperatively assess whether an adenoma is able to secrete both aldosterone and cortisol in order to avoid a possible postoperative adrenal insufficiency. Very few cases focusing on the development of adrenal insufficiency in patients undergoing Conn’s syndrome surgery have, however, been reported in the literature.20
In conclusion, this suggests that all patients undergoing adrenal surgery for Conn’s syndrome should be screened for glucocorticoid activity.

ack.p: Thanks to Dr Leonardo Rasciti, who is in charge of the approval of the “Group for Diagnosis and Treatment of Incidentally Discovered Adrenal Masses”, approved at the S. Orsola-Malpighi Hospital in May 2010.
